Available TUBA commands¶

Geometry Commands¶

Created on Sun Mar 27 22:05:19 2016

tuba.define_geometry.P(x, y, z, name='')[source]¶

Creates a tubapoint with the coordinates P(x,y,z,name)

tuba.define_geometry.V(x, y, z, name='')[source]¶

Creates a vector and an end point starting from the specified tubapoint. If no tubapoint-name is specified, the vector will be created starting from the last created point. The direction is defined by the user input x,y,z.

tuba.define_geometry.Vc(length, name='')[source]¶

Creates a colinear vector in direction of the last vector. (The information for the colinear vector is contained in current_tubapoint.Vd2x)

tuba.define_geometry.Vp(endpoint_name, startpoint_name='')[source]¶

Creates a vector from start_tubapoint to end_tubapoint. If no start_tubapoint is specified, the current_tubapoint is used as startpoint

tuba.define_geometry.Bent(radius, angle_deg='', orientation='', vector='', mode='intersect', name='')[source]¶

There are 2 general ways to create a pipe bent:

  1. Bent(bending_radius,vector=Vector3):

    arg1 as a vector defines the new direction after the bent With this function, it’s not possible to create 180°-bents as the bending plane is not defined. A workaround would be to define 2 consecutive 90°-bents or use the angle+orientaion mode

  2. Bent(bending_radius,angle=ang_Bent (in degree),orientation=ang_Orient(in degree) ):

    With the input arg1=bent angle and arg2=orientation angle (defined as a dihedral angle), the new direction after the bent can be calculated.

mode defines around which point the bent will be created. For “add” the start_tubapoint of the Bent will be the end_tubapoint of the last vector.

For “intersect” the last vector will be changed. Its end_tubapoint will be defined as intersection point of the current and new vector of the piping

tuba.define_geometry.gotoP(name_point)[source]¶

The function allowes to changes the current Tubapoint used for the next vector creation

Global Property Commands¶

Created on Tue Apr 5 01:20:46 2016

tuba.define_properties.Temperature(T=20, T_ref=20)[source]¶

Global Function:Applies the Temperature T to the following constructed Sections. T_ref is used to simulate cold springs.

At T=T_ref the thermal dilation is set to 0. So if you want to pretension a piping part so that at f.ex. T=300°C the thermal dilation is zero, T_ref has to be set to 300°C

tuba.define_properties.Pressure(pressure)[source]¶

Defines the internal Pressure of the piping system. For 3D and TUYAU models, this pressure is part of the simulation.

For TUBE -Elements this pressure is only taken into account for the postprocessing by superposing it with the simulation

results.

tuba.define_properties.Material(material)[source]¶

Global Function: Appends the choosen material to the following vector elements. The material properties can be defined in library_material.py

The material properties can be defines constant or as a function of temperature.

At the moment, the following materials are accessible:

“SS304” - f(Temperature)

“SS316” - f(Temperature)

“CSA53” - f(Temperature)

“Ax1” - constant

“A42” - constant

“IMS” - constant

“RIGIDE” - constant

“ACIER” - constant

tuba.define_properties.Pressure(pressure)[source]

Defines the internal Pressure of the piping system. For 3D and TUYAU models, this pressure is part of the simulation.

For TUBE -Elements this pressure is only taken into account for the postprocessing by superposing it with the simulation

results.

tuba.define_properties.RhoFluid(density_fluid)[source]¶

allows to take into account the weight of the fluid in the pipe.

tuba.define_properties.Insulation(insulation_thickness, insulation_density)[source]¶

by providing insulation thickness and density, this function allows to take into account the weight of the pipe insulation.

Local Property Commands¶

tuba.define_properties.Block(x='x', y='x', z='x', rx='x', ry='x', rz='x', reference='global')[source]¶

The Block function blocks the degree of freedoms of the last created point. Per default all components are set to ‘x’ which equals to no restriction on the DOF for the respective component. Setting a real value applies a restriction, whereas a value != to 0 implies a deflection/torsion of the point. There are several ways how to use it:

Block single compontents by naming –> B(x=0,rz=0) reference=”global” to block in direction of the global base reference=”local” to block in directions of the local base of the element

tuba.define_properties.Spring(x=0, y=0, z=0, rx=0, ry=0, rz=0, reference='global')[source]¶

appends a stiffness matrix to the current tubapoint.

Multiple stiffness matrixes can be summed up.

tuba.define_properties.Force(x=0, y=0, z=0, reference='global')[source]¶

appends a force-vector to the current tubapoint

Multiple force vectors can be summed up.

tuba.define_properties.Moment(rx=0, ry=0, rz=0, reference='local')[source]¶

appends a moment to the current tubapoint

Multiple moments can be summed up.

tuba.define_properties.LinearForce(x=0, y=0, z=0, reference='global')[source]¶

appends a linear force-vector to the last created vector. [N/mm]

Multiple force vectors can be summed up.

Macro Commands¶

Created on Mon Mar 28 21:31:36 2016

tuba.define_macros.FixPoint()[source]¶

Creates a fixed Point

tuba.define_macros.Joint()[source]¶

Restrains all 3 spatial directions but allows rotation around the axis

tuba.define_macros.Guide()[source]¶

A guide only allows movement in coaxial direction
